act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: chuck davis
utterance: Why do you have to come here? There's ground up there too for the public. From the Green River Lakes, there's millions and millions of acres of public ground, of national forest, of state ground. Why do you have to come on this specific piece of ground?

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: It looked nice. [LAUGHS]

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: chuck davis
utterance: Yeah, how long will it stay nice? How long will it continue to look nice if everybody comes down here-- and I'm not pointing a finger at you-- but if 10 people come through here and nine of them leave beer cans-- or even four of them-- every day, or build different fires and the fire ring is here, how long will this look nice? You've just got to draw the line somewhere.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: I apologized for my trespass and was quickly back on the river, paddling through some of the most beautiful country I'd ever seen and keeping my eye on both banks, the two lines I wouldn't cross again until sometime after dark.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: By mid-July, I had become tight and fit. I looked like a young boxer, and I tried not to think about anything. Backing up to the loading dock late on those days with a trunk of empties, I was full of animal happiness. And I moved with the measured deliberation the full day had given me. When I bent to the metal fountain beside the dock, gulping the water, I could feel it bloom on my back and my chest and come out along my hairline.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Around this time, a terrible thing happened in my phone correspondence with Linda Enright. We stopped fighting. We'd talk about her family. The cookie business was taking off, but her father wouldn't let her take the car. He was stingy. I told her about my deliveries, the heat.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: As I listened to us talk, I stood and wondered, "Who are these people?" The other me wanted to interrupt to ask, "Hey, didn't we have sex? I mean, was that sexual intercourse? Isn't the world a little different for you now?" But I chatted with her. When the operator came on, I was crazy with Linda's indifference but unable to say anything but, "Take care. I'll call."

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Meanwhile, the summer assumed a regularity that was nothing but comfort. I drove my routes. I was used to sitting with Gil Benson and hearing his stories, pocketing the Oreos secretly to throw them from the truck later. I was used to Elizabeth Rensdale showing me her white breasts, posturing by the pool whenever she knew I was upstairs with her father.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Driving the valley those long summer days, each window of the truck a furnace, listening to "Paperback Writer" and "Last Train to Clarksville," I delivered oxygen to the paralyzed and dying. And I felt so alive and on edge at every moment that I could've burst. I liked the truck, hopping up, unloading the hot cylinders at each address, and then driving to the next stop. I knew what I was doing and wanted no more.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Rain broke the summer. The second week in August, I woke to the first clouds in 90 days. They massed and thickened. And by the time I left Sun City, it had begun, a crashing downpour. I didn't want to be late at the Rensdales. I was wiping down the tank in the covered entry when Elizabeth opened the door and disappeared back into the dark house. I was wet from the warm rain, and coming into the air-conditioned house ran a chill along my sides. When my eyes adjusted and I started backing up the stairway with a new cylinder, I saw Elizabeth sitting on the couch in the den, her knees together up under her chin, watching me. She was looking right at me.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "This is the worst summer of my entire life," she said.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Sorry?" I said, coming down a step, "What'd you say?"

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "David, is that you?" Mr. Rensdale called from his room. His voice was a ghost. I liked him very much, and it had become clear over the summer that he was not going back to Pennsylvania.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Elizabeth Rensdale whispered across the room to me, "I don't want to be here." She closed her eyes and rocked her head. I stood the cylinder on the dolly and went over to her. I didn't like leaving it there on the carpet. She was sitting in her underpants on the couch.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "He's dying," she said to me.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Oh," I said, trying to make it simply a placeholder, let her know I'd heard her. She put her face in her hands and lay over on the couch. I dropped to a knee, and putting my hand on her shoulder, I said, "What can I do?"

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: This was the secret side that I had suspected from this summer. Elizabeth Rensdale put her hand on mine and turned her face to mine so slowly that I felt my heart drop a gear, grinding now heavily uphill in my chest. Mr. Rensdale called my name again. Elizabeth's face on mine, so close and open, made it possible for me to move my hand around her back and pull her to me. It was like I knew what I was doing. I didn't take my eyes from hers when she rolled onto her back and guided me onto her.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I wish I could get this right here, but there was no chance. We stayed together for a moment afterward, and my eyes opened and focused. She was still looking at me, holding me. And her look was simply serious. Her father called, "David?" from upstairs again, and I realize he must have been calling steadily.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Mr. Rensdale lay white and twisted in the bed. He looked the way the dying look, his face parched and sunken, the mouth a dry orifice, his eyes little spots of water. I saw him acknowledge me with a withering look, more power than you'd think could rise from such a body. And I moved in the room deliberate with shame, avoiding his eyes.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: He rolled his hand in a little flip toward the bed table and his glass of water. Who knows what happened in me then? Because I stood in the little bedroom with Mr. Rensdale, and then I just rolled the dolly and the expired tank out and down the stairs. I didn't go to him. I didn't hand him the glass of water. I burned. Who would ever know what I have done?

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: Sand Wash is way out in the Utah desert. You drive two and a half hours on a dirt road. And when you get there, it's a big canyon, a dry wash cutting down through shale stone badlands, and emptying into the Green River. The river at this point is slow and flat, the color of coffee with milk, and just about as warm.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: If you stand by the river, you might see a Great Blue Heron, a pair of Golden Eagles, a beaver, an otter. The river is a thin, snake-like oasis. But if you turn away from the water and look back up at the cliffs and barren plateaus, you might think you're now living on a dry, god-forsaken planet. It's just the Utah desert, close to where Rubin Farr buried his cat. Close to nowhere.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: This desert is controlled by the Bureau of Land Management. They manage the grazing permits, and they give out 10,000 floating permits every year to people who want to make the six- or seven-day trip down through Desolation Canyon. There's a BLM ranger stationed there, where you put your boat in the water. Her name is Michelle Sturm. She's six feet tall and carries a clipboard. She checks your permit, checks your equipment-- first aid kit, extra paddles, life jacket. She jokes around, doesn't give you a hard time. And it's easy to see she's not from around here, that she's on some kind of leave of absence, hiding out in the wilderness.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: I came off of working with homeless for two and a half years-- mentally ill adults and single males and hungry people and low income families in downtown San Jose, California, and was really just tired and not enough joy in my life. I wanted to be in the middle of nowhere. So the first night I was at Sand Wash, I really felt at home and comfortable, and this was the right place.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: And the light and the wind-- the factors that are really important and have bearing on your life are real significant factors, things you have absolutely no control over. And you can write by the moon at night. At night, these loud-- I don't know what they are-- sort of airplane-type bugs. But I don't think they're dragonflies, but something else just comes zooming in and zooming by the bedroom window and checking things out. And the bats are really fun. They come really close.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: And I hear boaters. And I hear people coming down the gravel road, and that's always a little apprehensive, as I don't know what they want.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: Are you going to go back to working with homeless people?

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: I don't think so. I don't think so. I think you need to have a strong faith and religious belief to do that kind of work. And I think I tend to see it more as a political situation rather than a religious situation. And so it just really produces more anger than saintliness or something.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: So you're angry.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: Angry.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: What are you upset about? What bothers--

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: Well, the thing that bothers you is that you and everyone you're working with is doing as much as you possibly can. And yet, you can't do enough. And someone else has asked you for something else, and you can't do it. And you learn to have to say no.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: michelle sturm
utterance: That's a pretty dismal way to operate. You don't want to have to operate always feeling your boundaries, and if I just keep stretching and stretching, I'm going to break, and so I have to protect myself so I don't break. And then I let all these people down. You see?

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: What you see are shadows in the moonlight, the mouth of the canyon, the eerie shapes of red rock walls, the figure of a tall woman walking home to bed.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Scott Carrier on the Green River in Utah.

act_title: Act One: Act One
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Coming up, finding a dead body and not finding one. In a minute, when our program continues.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ira glass
utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Each week on our program, of course, we choose a theme, bring you a variety of stories on that theme. Today's show, The Promise of Summer.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ira glass
utterance: And rather than bring you a big bunch of stories this hour, we're interlacing two stories throughout the hour. One from Scott Carrier traveling down the Green River in Utah. One from Ron Carlson, a short story called "Oxygen" from his new book of stories, Hotel Eden. Before we get back to this story is a quick warning to listeners that Ron Carlson's story contains adult situations. No explicit language, but adult situations that might not be right for every listener.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: So the last month of that summer, I began seeing Elisabeth Rensdale every day. I told my parents I was at the library because I wanted it to sound like a lie and have them know it was a lie. I came in after midnight. The library closed at 9:00.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Elizabeth and I were hardy and focused lovers. Knowing we had two hours, we used every minute of it, and we became experts at each other. We never went out for a Coke. We never took a break for a glass of water. We rarely spoke. There was admiration and curiosity in my touch and affection and gratitude in hers, or so I assumed. And I was pleased, even proud, at the time that there was so little need to speak.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Meanwhile, Gil Benson had begun clinging to me worse than ever, and those prolonged visits were full of agony and desperation. I had never had such a thing happen before. And until it did, I thought of myself as a compassionate person. I watch myself arrive at his terrible house and wheel the tank toward the door, and I search myself for compassion, the smallest shred of fellow feeling, kindness, affection, pity. But all I found was repulsion, impatience. Give me the truck keys and a job to do. I had no compassion for Gil Benson.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: The Sunday before Labor Day, I didn't call Linda Enright. In each minute of the day, Linda Enright was in my mind. I saw her there in her green sweater by her father's rolltop. We always talked about what we were wearing, and she always said the green sweater, saying it innocently, as if wearing the sweater that I'd helped pull over her head that night was of little note, a coincidence, and not the most important thing that she'd say in the whole $8 call.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: And I'd say, just Levi's and a t-shirt, hoping she'd imagine the belt, the buckle, the trouble it could all be in the dark. I saw her sitting in the afternoon shadow, maybe writing some notes in her calendar or reading, and right over there, the telephone. I could get up and hit the phone booth in less than 10 minutes and make that phone ring, have her reach for it. But I didn't. I'll let her sit there until the last sunlight rocked through the den, broke, and disappeared.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: The last day of my job in the summer of 1967, I thought-- and this is the truth-- I thought for the first time of what I was going to say last to Elizabeth Rensdale. I tried to imagine it, and my imagination failed. When I climbed from her bed the nights I'd gone to her, it was just that-- climbing out, dressing, and crossing to the door. She didn't get up. This wasn't Casablanca or High Noon or Captain Blood. This was getting laid in a hot summer desert town by your father's oxygen delivery man. There was no way to make it anything else.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Some of my customers knew I was leaving and made kind remarks or shook my hand or had their wife hand me an envelope with a twenty in it. I smiled and nodded gratefully, and then turned, business-like, to the dolly and left. These were strange goodbyes because there was no question that we would ever see each other again. It had been a summer, and I had been their oxygen guy.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: But there was more. I was young and they were ill. I stood in the bedroom doors in Sun City and said, take care. And I moved to the truck and felt something, but I couldn't even today tell you what it was. To the people who didn't know, who said, "See you next week, David," I didn't correct them. I said, "See you," and I left their homes too. It all had me on edge.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: The rain moved in for the day, persistent and even, and the temperature stalled and hovered at about 100. I thought Gil would be pleased to see me so soon in the day. But I surprised him, knocking at the door for five full minutes before he unlocked it, looking scared. Though I had told him I would eventually be going back to college, I hadn't told him this was my last day.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: There was no chatter right off the bat, no sitting down at the table. He just moved things out of the way as I wheeled the oxygen in and changed tanks. He stood to one side, leaning against the counter. When I finished, he made no move to keep me there, so I just kept going. At the front door, I said, "There you go. Good luck, Gil."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: His name quickened him, and he came after me with short steps in his slippers. "Well, yes," he started as always. "I wouldn't need this stuff at all if I'd stayed out of the war." And he was off and cranking. But when I went outside, he followed me into the rain. "You've got to go," I told him. "It's wet out here."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: His wet skin in the light looked raw, the spots on his forehead brown and liquid. Under his eyes, the skin was purple. I'd let him get too close to the truck, and he grabbed the door handle.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "I wasn't sick a day in my life," he said. "Ask my wife."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I put my hand on his on the door handle, and I knew I wasn't going to be able to pry it off without breaking it. Gil Benson pulled the truck door open and with surprising dexterity, he stepped up into the vehicle, sitting on all my paperwork. I looked at Gil, shrunken and purple in the darkness of the cab. He looked like the victim of a fire.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Gil," I said. "I'm late." I looked at him, but he did not look at me. He sat still, his eyes timid, frightened, smug. It was an expression you use when you want someone to hit you. I started the truck, hoping that would scare him, but he did not move. His eyes were still floating, and it looked like he was grinning, but it wasn't a grin. I kicked my door open and jumped down into the red mud and went around the front of the truck.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: When I opened his door, he did not turn or look at me, which was fine with me. I lifted Gil like a bride, and he clutched me, his face wet against my face. I carried him to the front door. He was light and bony like an old bird. And I was strong, and I felt strong, but I could tell this was an insult the old man didn't need. When I stood him there, he would not let go, his hands clasped around my neck. And I peeled his hands apart carefully, easily, and I folded them back toward him so he wouldn't snag me again.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Goodbye, Gil," I said. He was an old man alone in the desert. He did not acknowledge me.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: It happened in Desolation Canyon, a wilderness, a place of natural forces. But there was nothing about the river except a few easily negotiated rapids, nothing about the weather except a strong gust of wind at sunset, and nothing about the night, except the pulses of some distant heat lightning. There was nothing to explain the blue plastic ground cloth rolled around the body of a small, 16-year-old boy.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: This plastic, set on the floor of a rubber raft, the raft pulled up on a beach below a dirt road where the airplane would land, the young friend of the boy asleep on the sand, bleached blond hair, necklace, smooth, tense skin. A child. This man, an instructor, who came to fly the body out of the canyon.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: man
utterance: The boy who died was a 16-year-old student. And he died yesterday, on the seventh day of the course. He was discovered by a fellow student at his campsite at about 10:50 PM with no apparent pulse or breathing. And cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed for 44 minutes.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: As far as you know, the death didn't have anything to do with the river or being on the river.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: man
utterance: I'm quite sure that wasn't the case.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: Do you have any ideas of what was the cause?

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: man
utterance: At this point, no, I don't. I'm sure that the coroner's report will tell us what it was, but I can't say. I couldn't speculate.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: What's it like? What's it-- I don't know how to ask that question, but what's it like when one of your students dies?

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: man
utterance: Traumatic, heartrending, for not only the instructors but fellow students. It's been a difficult 24 hours. It'll continue to be so.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: You know, a river has its own space and time. Earth dissolves into water, water into air. And death is like a river. You stand next to it, and all the words fall out of your head.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I radioed Nadine that the rain had slowed me up, and I wouldn't make it back before 5:00.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "No problem, sonny boy," she said. "Over."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "I'll hit the Rensdales and on in. Over."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Sonny boy," she said. "Just pick up there. Mr. Rensdale died yesterday. Remember the portable unit, OK? And good luck at school. Stop in if you're down for Christmas break. Over."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I waited a minute to over and out to Nadine while the news subsided in me. It was on Scottsdale Road at Camelback where I turned right. That corner will always be that radio call. "Copy. Over," I said.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: In front of the Rensdale's townhouse, I felt odd going to the door with the empty dolly. I rang the bell, and after a moment, Elizabeth appeared. She was barefoot in jeans and a t-shirt, and she looked at me.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "I'm sorry about your father," I said. "This is tough."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: She stared at me, and I held the gaze. "I mean it. I'm sorry."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: She drifted back into the house. I pulled the dolly up the stairs to Mr. Rensdales room. It'd been taken apart a little bit, the bed stripped, our gear all standing in the corner. With Mr. Rensdale gone, you could see what the room was, just a little box in the desert.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "I'm going back Friday." Elizabeth had come into the room. "I guess I'm going back to school."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Good," I said. I didn't know what I was saying. I started to say something else, but she pointed at me.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Don't come. Just do what you do, but don't come to the funeral. You don't have to."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "I want to," I said. Her tone had hurt, made me mad. I walked to the bed and put my hands on her shoulders.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Don't."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I bent and looked into her face.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Don't."

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I went to pull her toward me to kiss, and she leaned away sharply. "Don't, David." But I followed her over onto the bed, and though she squirmed tight as a knot, I held her beside me, adjusting her, drawing her back against me. About a minute later, she said, "What are you doing?"

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "It's OK," I said.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Then she put her hand on my wrist, stopping it. "Don't," she said. "What are you doing?"

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Elizabeth," I said, kissing at her nape.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: She rose to an elbow and looked at me, her face rock hard, unfamiliar. Our eyes were locked. "Is this what you came for?" She lay back and thumbed off her pants. "Is it?"

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Yes," I said. It was the truth, and there was pleasure in saying it.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: "Then go ahead." She moved to the edge of the bed.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: She didn't move when I pulled away, just lay there looking at me. I remember it as the moment in this life when I was farthest from any of my feelings. I gathered the empty cylinder and the portable gear with the strangest thought. It's going to take me 20 years to figure out who I am now.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I could feel Elizabeth Rensdale's hatred as I would feel it dozens of times a season for many years. It's a kind of dread for me that has become a rudder and kept me out of other troubles. The next year at school, I used it to treat Linda Enright correctly, as a gentleman, and keep my distance. I had the chance to win her back, and I did not take it.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I left for my junior year of college at Missoula three days later. The evening before my flight, my parents took me to dinner at a steakhouse on a mesa, a Western place where they cut your tie off if you wear one. My parents were proud of me, they said, working hard like this all summer away from my friends. I was changing, they said. And they could tell it was for the better.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: Much, much later, I drove the dark streets. The radio played a steady rotation of exactly the same songs heard today on every 50,000 watt station in this country. Every fifth song was The Supremes. I knew where I was going. Beyond the bright, rough edge of the lights of Mesa, I drove until the pavement ended. And then I dropped onto the red clay roads and found Gil Benson's house.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I knocked and called for minutes. Out back, I kicked through the debris and weeds until I found one of the back bedroom windows unlocked. And I slid it open and climbed inside. In the stale heat, I knew immediately that the house was abandoned. I called Gil's name and picked my way carefully to the hall. The lights did not work.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: I wasn't scared, but I was something else. Standing in that dark room where I had palmed old Oreos all summer long, I now had proof-- hard proof-- that I had lost Gil Benson. He hadn't made it back, and I couldn't wish him back.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ron carlson
utterance: At home, my suitcases were packed. Some big thing was closing down in me. I had spent the summer as someone else, someone I knew I didn't care for, and I would be glad when he left town. We would see each other from time to time, but I also knew he was no friend of mine. I eased along the empty roadways trying simply to gather what was left, to think. But it was like trying to fold a big blanket alone. I kept having to start over.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: The sun is going down, and three families are camped beside a trout stream in southern Utah. The women are talking to each other by the picnic table. The men are watching the children play in the water. Two of the women are sisters. One has just had an affair with a man in Los Angeles. On the phone, she swore to her sister that she would tell her husband and insist on a divorce. But now, she's thinking she will not say anything ever about the affair and maybe wait a while on the divorce.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: Her sister is swaying back and forth with a baby in her arms. This morning, the baby stuck her right hand in a cup of hot coffee and cried for hours. Now she's asleep, but her fingers have big, balloon-like blisters that will break and heal slowly, leaving long, white scars.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: The third woman is two days pregnant and thinking about taking a nap. Of the men, one is trying to decide when would be the best time to drive into town and call his broker. One is thinking about running up the mountain to smoke a joint and watch the sun go down. The other is looking at the water wondering if the fish might like a grasshopper.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: The children are playing and fighting over a toy sailboat. The three-year-old boy is soaking wet and nearly out of his mind with the possibilities. The five-year-old girl is standing on the bank, making up rules and shouting out orders and dropping lettuce and cheese from her sandwich. There are little birds in the trees and big birds on the rock walls of the canyon-- red rock walls in the shadow of the afternoon sun.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: A dirt road comes around and down and crosses over the stream, and in the pool below the road, a pale snake slides silently into the water and swims to the other side, holding something rather large in its mouth. There are three cars, all white, and there's an Indian-- or rather, the ghost of an Indian who lived and died in this spot-- sitting cross-legged on the hood of the station wagon.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: scott carrier
utterance: This is the beginning of a story. The story is about how the husband realizes his wife has been unfaithful. And it's about how the Indian died and what the snake had in its mouth and how the two-day-old life inside the mother grows and is born and becomes a beautiful young woman who paints the poems of Rilke on the desert blacktop highway. The sun is going down, and three families are camped beside a trout stream in southern Utah. This is the beginning of a story, but there isn't enough time to tell it.

act_title: Act Two: On The Green River
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Scott Carrier, and Ron Carlson before him.

utterance: I'm Ira Glass, back next week with more stories of This American Life.

ep-640.utterance: We would all go to the pool together, and I had this tie dyed bathing suit, this one-piece. And you know, like, most of my other friends were, like, wearing bikinis. But you know, it was like, no, I'm good.

ep-640.utterance: At the snack bar, they would get popsicles.

ep-640.speaker: onnesha

ep-640.speaker: chana joffe-walt
ep-640.utterance: It would have been nothing if it was like the other girls they talked about, a passing thing. But this one persisted for weeks.

And I can't remember how I found out, but eventually I found out it was me.

ep-640.speaker: chana joffe-walt
ep-640.utterance: It was the first time Onnesha had the feeling. There was her, and there was someone else she hadn't known was there, a person who looked good to these boys, her friends.

ep-640.speaker: chana joffe-walt
ep-640.utterance: Another person who is you?

ep-640.speaker: onnesha
